Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Gas laws, thermodynamic functions, first and second laws of Thermodynamics, phase diagrams, physical properties of mixtures, thermodynamic aspects of equilibria, electrochemistry, and kinetics.
This class was a slightly more advanced version of gen chem. We learned about thermo, with some basic calc thrown in.
A decent understanding of thermodynamics, and a little bit of electrochemistry and kinetics

One of the TAs for this course told us "it takes learning about thermodynamics about 4 times before you really get it. Once in gen chem. Once in p chem. Then twice more in grad school. That's when you realize you've kind of gotten it wrong all those other times, but NOW you get it." 

Don't expect to come out of this course knowing everything about gases, thermodynamic relations, phases, equilibrium, and kinetics. But DO expect to have a much deeper appreciation past the surface-level for how complex these topics truly are and the cool math that goes into describing them. If you're taking this class you probably have to, but really no reason to dread it. It can be kind of fun.

I learned the basics of physical chemistry (gases, thermo, phase diagrams, simple mixtures, equilibrium and electrochemistry, kinetics). However, we got behind, so we were not able to cover these topics in depth.
Partial derivatives.gases, liquids, and solids and how they interact with each other. Thermodynamics
I developed the necessary skills for thinking properly about thermodynamics in particular.
This class taught me mostly about critical thinking and more about thermodynamics than I ever cared to know.

The course serves a strong continuation / reinforcement of general chemistry principles in a more mathematically rigorous and/or thorough way. You will cover ideal gas theory which transitions into thermodynamics, on which you will spend most of the semester. This includes but is not limited to the three fundamental laws of thermodynamics and their manipulations for different environmental conditions (isothermal, adiabatic, etc). You will develop relations for work and entropy. This will inform the study of solution chemistry, electrochemistry, equilibria and kinetics.

I learned a lot of cool concepts that really changed my view of chemistry as a whole. For instance, instead of thinking of matter in broad terms like solids, liquids, and gases, it's cool to get a little exposure to the underlying molecular/atomic motions and interactions. Super cool stuff.

I learned a little bit about gasses, a little bit about work and thermodynamics, a little bit about multiple component mixtures, and a little bit about kinetics. Honestly, most of the material had already been covered for me in general chemistry, so I don't feel like I learned too much.

You learn a lot about the macroscopic aspects of physical chemistry. The majority of the semester is focused on thermodynamics, and, at the end of the semester, you touch upon equilibria, electrochemistry, and kinetics. It was neat to learn more about thermodynamics besides the very surface-level explanations that are taught in 165/167.
In 332, you cover the topics of Thermodynamics, Mixtures, Equilibria, and Kinetics from Physical Chemistry.
Introductory Pchem knowledge about gases, thermodynamics, equilibrium, and kinetics.
I learned physical chemistry's foundational concepts, refreshed some calculus concepts like partial derivatives and exact/inexact differentials, and how to pace myself in tests!
My quantitative analysis is much more direct and I have mastered topics introduced in general chemistry.
none! like actually none
Physical chemistry skills.
Kinematics and thermo
Gained some general knowledge about physical chemistry concepts.
Nothing
Mostly a review of Chem 163/167 concepts with a deeper look into the material. Great overview of Thermodynamics that helped a lot with the Thermodynamics course I was also taking.
Basic of physical chemistry such as gases, thermodynamics, electrochemistry, and equilibrium
Thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, etc.
Really in-depth knowledge of chemistry, which was cool

Learned a general overview of physical chemistry including topics such as ideal and real gases, thermodynamics, ideal and real solutions, ideal and real mixtures, phase diagrams, electrochemistry, and chemical kinetics
Physical chemistry is used in a lot of other classes, so I learned a lot of necessary material.
I learned how to think about physical chemistry. How to take a more quantitative approach to chemistry.
This is course is very well designed.

This course is not that hard (do not lets its reputation scare you!). The lectures are not that helpful because they seem so simple. The psets are not that long and good. Section was helpful because it gave you problems that were comparable to the ones on the exams. The exams were unexpectedly hard, but the curve is really in your favor. Prof. Schmuddy has wonderful intentions, but his lectures are sort of frantic and confusing. He is very fair and kind.
The textbook was good. The lectures were slow yet slightly confusing. The problem sets were short and did not reflect the style of exam questions. More practice problems would have been good.
The greatest strength is professor follows the same path as the book so it is easy to learn the material because if you dont understand something its easy to find in the book and relearn it.
The course could be improved by selecting a textbook that did not dilute the important information as much.

Problem sets were due weekly, worth only 5%, and not very representative of the test questions themselves. Section was helpful only if you had a grasp on the material before hand, as a worksheet was provided and simply done together on the board. The text book is very necessary in this class (and I would recommend getting the correct edition - as the previous edition had several typos in formulas that resulted in a lot of wasted time trying to figure out). Prof is good about explaining the concepts enough using examples and deriving equations, but reading the textbook is necessary for background material and understanding the concepts more conceptually.

This is a good course. Professor Schmuttenmaer can be a little unorganized, and will fall well behind the syllabus. But in general, the material is engaging as a continuation of Chem163/167. Very little of what we covered felt like it was much more advanced or outside the scope of material introduced by Professor Zilm in 167. To this end, the course in integral in solidifying the foundation of basic physical chemistry for any chem, engineering, or other physical sciences major.

This course was very well-taught and well-organized.  My only improvement would be to make midterm exams a bit shorter.  They are extremely long for the difficulty.  I feel that a lot of students found their only problem to be time, and not mastery of the material.

I really liked the Fermi questions, I think practicing those on every pset gives you a pretty good sense of the logic needed to make estimations/approximations (a pretty useful skill). 

I think the course could be improved by going a little faster, I feel like we didn't learn a ton of stuff and I would've liked to!

The course was way too slow. I honestly found my gen chem 2 course more challenging and rigorous than this class. If I am going to spend a semester of my time studying something, I want to either learn something new or at least gain appreciable detail in the study of something old. I did neither this semester. I think the best way to improve this class would be to recognize that most of the students already have a solid grip on the much of the material, pick up the pace. Too much time was spent on PV=nRT, what a partial derivative is, and so on...

The strengths are that Schmuttenmaer is a very fair professor, and his tests are very fair and representative of the homework/practice problems. If you read the textbook, you can do very well in the course even if you didn't understand one of the lectures. Sometimes Schmuttenmaer's lectures are a bit disorganized, making it hard to follow, but, overall, I think the course was fairly decent.

The strength is that the textbook is quite clear at explaining the material.  The weakness is that Prof. Schmuttenmaer, though a kind guy that means well, can get a bit disorganized during lectures and sometimes didn't explain concepts fully.

Strengths: The class follows the textbook almost exactly, making it very easy to follow along.
Weaknesses: The lectures were pretty disorganized and hard to understand. Would definitely recommend getting a textbook and reading along as the lectures progress.
The class followed the book very closely, which is a big plus for when you're lost on a concept. Sometimes the proofs to the concepts could be made more explicit in class.

The first half of the semester was really fun - lots of demonstrations and interesting examples. Prof. Schmuttenmeyer was energetic and explained topics clearly, though often only after direct questions. The last part of the course was more dry, maybe because of the rush to finish the syllabus.
In general, the exams were a bit weird--they tested material that we briefly covered or random tangents that the professor mentioned in class.
The course could be more organized, and the tests could better reflect the material that we went over in class.
I wish that we had gone over some basic example problems in class instead of only learning theory/derivations.

I don't think that section was as useful as it could have been, I feel like the TAs didn't really know what they were doing at times. The professor also didn't seem to know what he was doing sometimes. Overall, this was quite a confusing course.

Great overview of Thermodynamics, I like the book being used - its very clear and presents the information super well (contrasting with the book my Thermo class was using which was terrible). Professor Schmuttenmaer was super enthusiastic and a very sympathetic professor. I think the material should be gone through faster so we get through the entire curriculum though which would happen with better organization.
I guess I just wasn't sure how to do better. I studied hard, knew the material, went to section. Yet never managed to get above 90 in the exams. I am very disappointed.

Strengths: 1. The course content is pretty decent and interesting. 2.The book is good and you can learn quite a bit from it. 3. He offers ample previous practice exams and finals, making it easy to see the style of questions 4. The TFs made worksheets that were similar to exam questions and strong  enough to actually be useful

Weaknesses: 1. Professor wasted a lot of time in class failing with demonstraction and we fell very behind. We spent 2 classes on electrochemistry and 3 classes on kinetics. We didn't get to photoredox or any other stuff. That's ridiculous, especially given kinetics and photoredox are amongst the most important subjects for organic and inorganic chemists. 2. The homework doesn't really reflect the exams, given they are from the book and thus very, very mathematical. 3. The book doesn't entire reflect what he emphasizes in class 4. Exams were too easy or too hard and thus the averages were always awkward, making it tough to know your placement in a class. 4.
Sometimes the exam questions don't seem to reflect what we've learned.

Strengths: Educational, great textbook, interesting material
Weaknesses: Prof sometimes got distracted during lecture, grade is 100% curve-based so you better be smarter than everyone else in the room
The professor and TAs were great. The only thing that would make it better is another set of practice tests.
Unnecessary to have three class times as well as a section. There were ample resources however to succeed in the class.

The course was great except for two things: Some tests were such that no matter how much I studied I probably would not have been able to answer some questions and the lecture could have been more informative if we talk about irrelevant material (even though doing so made lecture fun).
Its a pretty bad course overall. Im not sure. The strengths were the TAs. The weakness was that nobody could really answer your questions, sometimes information was presented incorrectly, etc.

The strengths are that this course can somewhat be self-taught by following the textbook, to which the course material flows quite well with. It is also a fun and engaging course thanks to Prof. Schmuttenmaer. On the downside, the lessons and derivations were sometimes disjointed due to time, which was a function of the demos and videos we see (not that I'm complaining).
I would recommend this course to any student who wants to learn more about thermodynamics.
Take it because its not that hard (but also not that rewarding).
If this is required of you, take it and have fun. If you're thinking of taking this class for fun: you're a fascinating human being, and I hope you also take this class and have fun.
The materials is very interesting, so yes.
Yes! Im much better at math, application, and I have a greater understanding of solids, liquids, and gases and how they interact.
Yes, this is a great course, and you learn a lot, provided that you have the time to put into it.

This class does require a moderate amount of work to succeed. I spent all my time this semester focused on pchem lab that I often neglected the work for this course. Cramming the night before an exam does not really work, as exam questions require critical thinking about integrating different concepts. Classes build off the previous class, so understanding the material as it is taught is the only way to not actually get lost in lecture.

If you're taking this course, you likely have to. But all things considered I enjoyed this course. The pace and expectations were reasonable. Exams are often time pressured and Professor Schmuttenmaer has a habit of putting quirky questions, somewhat out of left field. But all in all you'll walk out of Chem332a with an appreciable understanding of chemical thermodynamics,  a foundation to the physical sciences.
I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in chemistry. The chemistry department at Yale is wonderful.
Yep, it provides a good baseline for understanding pchem concepts.

Don't take it unless you need to for your major. There are so many more interesting things to do with your time at Yale. I came into the class expecting it to be one of my favorites because I'm a chem nerd, but I was rather disappointed by the content of the class. The material we covered was really just gen-chem for marginally more complex systems. That being said, if you do have to take this class, you will be relieved to hear that the material isn't that challenging despite its boring nature.
No. Unless you have to take it, take the physics class for thermodynamics.

I would recommend this class to another student. There are very few chemistry professors who will write tests as fairly as Schmuttenmaer will. Be warned about a few things before entering this class. This class is very deceptive in the sense that you can float through the semester not really paying attention and then all of a sudden bomb a test if you don't prepare well for it. It doesn't require an insane amount of preparation, but you should still prepare decently well (hint: read the textbook, which is very clear and concise on everything taught). There are three groups of people taking the class. The first is the MB&B majors who are taking this over the other CHEM 328 (which is taught poorly from what I understand); these people seemed to have no interest in the class and seemed a bit frazzled. The second group of people are the chemistry majors. They want to enjoy the class, but most of them are terrorized by p chem lab and are completely deceased when it comes to CHEM 332. In fact, many chem majors don't come to lecture at all becuase they are so preoccupied with p chem lab. Be warned: this class becomes meaningless while taking p chem lab because all of your time will be focused there; many chem majors received lower grades than they wanted/expected because they just didn't have the time to devote to this class. The third group of people are the chemical engineering kids. These are the MOST ANNOYING group of people I have probably ever witnessed in a class. All of the Chem E kids have already learned a vast majority of the material from other courses, and they are extremely arrogant and disrespectful to the TAs and Schmuttenmaer frequently (talking loudly in class, correcting Schmuttenmaer when he makes a small mistake and snickering about it, acting like they know more than the TAs, etc). They are all (not all, but most) annoying twats who need to learn to be respectful (particularly @the group of sophomore boys). Everyone else in the class was visibly annoyed by the Chem E kids during lecture/section. Schmuttenmaer is a very nice man, and I enjoyed him as a professor. He is quite humorous if you are awake enough to go to class at 9am. Other students are quite harsh towards Schmuttenmaer, which confuses me a bit, because they clearly have not experienced many other (poorly) taught STEM courses at Yale in order to realize that Schmuttenmaer is pretty decent.

If you are a chemE or chemistry major, you are required to take this course, so I suggest that you read ahead in the textbook if possible during the semester to be familiar with the material before you see it in class.  If this course is not required for your major, I don't really see why you would take this course, as there are more interesting (and probably easier) science credit awarding courses, but if you happen to love physical chemistry, then godspeed.

Only if it is required for the major. Supposed better than CHEM 328 (the biological applications version). But the lectures are pretty not useful, so be prepared to do a lot of self-studying from the textbook.
Yup! It's usually required for your major.

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone interested in advanced chemistry and with a solid math background. It would be easy to get lost if someone didn't understand how to take chemistry courses.

NO and not with schmuttenmaer. honestly i only have terrible things to say about this lecture with this prof. he has absolutely no idea how to teach and going to lectures was the biggest waste of time EVER. i cannot recommend that you dont take this class with him. honestly exams were hogwash!  like you wont learn anything i would give this course a 0 if i could
If you enjoyed general chemistry go ahead and take it.
Schmuttenmaer is a pretty good lecturer--he is really clear and his notes are good, and the textbook also helps a lot.  It's a hard class, but you'll get through it.

Obviously if you're reading this you already know you have to take it soooooooooo. Pchem the class, on its own, is honestly not that bad. Schmutty is super entertaining and will have lots of fun demonstrations and he knows what he's talking about. The real problem with the class is doing it with all your other classes. This is definitely a class that you have to buy the book for -- an older edition will be fine -- but you really will benefit a lot from seeing how the book explains things over the way Schmutty does. the problem with this is that actually reading the book takes a solid chunk of time and the psets will take a decent bit of time too, except you will not have any time this semester if you are in pchem lab. The hardest part about this class is needing to devote a reasonable amount of time to it to succeed but having negative time because of writing pchem lab reports.
I mean, if you have to take it, you have to. I generally wouldn't recommend this course.
Yes, compared to all my other required science classes this was probably the best.
Interesting class.
Nobody takes this class because they want to without any gain, and we all know that.
Yeah, it's an easy sixth or seventh class. The first half is about moderate in difficulty, but then it goes back to some gen chem concepts.

Prof sometimes got distracted during lecture, grade is 100% curve-based so you better be smarter than everyone else in the room. If you're just trying to get this out of the way and you're a bio major who doesn't like chem, take the other class. If you're interested in the material/willing to maybe do worse, then this is worth it. Also  if you took freshman orgo sit yourself down and have a serious discussion with your soul about if you actually remember gen chem because I was so sure I did and did not, in fact, remember much gen chem and it kicked my ASS before I got that cleared up
Yes it is a very important class and Professor Schmuttenmaer is great. He is a good teacher and cares about whether or not his students learn.

As someone whos not chem or Cheme taking this course, I would say you should take it only if you are interested in more advance chemistry. It is very possible to take this with just having done gen chem and diff eq.
I thought the class extremely interesting.
No. Dont take this unless you have to. It was unnecessarily stressful and you really dont feel like youve learned all that much. Id recommend taking something else if you can.
Yes, this is about as good a course on the subject as anyone could expect.
